description: An overview of key technologies that have shaped the production, distribution, and consumption of music.

technologies.name: Sound Recording
technologies.description: The ability to capture sound waves and store them for later playback. This fundamentally changed music from a purely live experience to a repeatable commodity.
key_milestones: Phonograph (Thomas Edison, 1877): First device to record and reproduce sound.
Gramophone (Emile Berliner, 1887): Used flat discs, enabling mass production.
Magnetic Tape Recording (1930s-40s): Allowed for multi-track recording and editing.
Digital Recording (1970s-Present): Conversion of audio into digital data, offering lossless copies and powerful editing.

technologies.name: MIDI (Musical Instrument Digital Interface)
technologies.description: A technical standard that describes a protocol, digital interface, and connectors that allow a wide variety of electronic musical instruments, computers, and other related devices to connect and communicate with one another. MIDI carries event messages, not audio signals.
key_milestones: Standardization in 1983 by companies like Roland, Sequential Circuits, and Yamaha.
Adoption in computers, making home studio production possible.
MIDI 2.0 (2020): Expanded capabilities with higher resolution and more expressive control.

technologies.name: Digital Audio Workstation (DAW)
technologies.description: A software application for recording, editing, and producing audio files. DAWs are the centerpiece of modern music production, integrating MIDI sequencing, audio recording, and mixing into a single program.
key_milestones: Cubase Audio (1991) and Pro Tools (1991) were among the first integrated MIDI and audio DAWs.
Rise of accessible DAWs like FL Studio and Ableton Live in the late 90s/early 2000s democratized music production.

technologies.name: Audio Compression (MP3)
technologies.description: Algorithms that reduce the file size of digital audio. The MP3 format became the de facto standard for music distribution over the internet.
key_milestones: Napster (1999): A peer-to-peer file sharing service that dramatically highlighted the impact of digital distribution and copyright issues.

technologies.name: Streaming Services
technologies.description: Online platforms that provide on-demand access to vast libraries of music. This has become the dominant model for music consumption.
key_milestones: Spotify launched (2008): Popularized the 'access over ownership' subscription model.
Rise of algorithmic playlists and music discovery.

technologies.name: Generative AI in Music
technologies.description: Artificial intelligence models capable of generating novel musical compositions, including melodies, harmonies, rhythms, and even vocals, often from text prompts.
key_milestones: OpenAI's Jukebox and MuseNet demonstrated early capabilities.
Suno AI and Udio (2023-2024): Publicly available models that can generate complete, high-quality songs with vocals from text prompts, marking a significant leap in AI music generation.
